items.title: Construction from string fraction fails
items.body:
Should initialization with a string fraction work like it does with Decimal or does this intentionally fail?

```python
>>> data=[Money('1/3', 'USD')]*10
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<ipython-input-4-65ba518eef3f>", line 1, in <module>
    data=[Money('1/3', 'USD')]*10
  File "/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/lib/python3.8/site-packages/moneyed/classes.py", line 83, in __init__
    amount = Decimal(str(amount))
InvalidOperation: [<class 'decimal.ConversionSyntax'>]
>>> >>> Money(1, 'USD') / 3
<Money: 0.3333333333333333333333333333 USD>
```

https://docs.python.org/3/library/decimal.html

items.title: Why is ROUND_HALF_EVEN the default everywhere?
items.body:
Why is ROUND_HALF_EVEN used across all the formatting definitions? It would seem to me like decimal.ROUND_HALF_UP is the proper one to use?

```
In [40]: Decimal("2953.125").quantize(Decimal("1.00"), decimal.ROUND_HALF_EVEN)
Out[40]: Decimal('2953.12')

In [41]: Decimal("2953.125").quantize(Decimal("1.00"), decimal.ROUND_HALF_UP)
Out[41]: Decimal('2953.13')
```

I'm from Sweden. Here it should definitely be 2953.13, but it's probably different for other currencies?

From localization.py:

```
_format("sv_SE", group_size=3, group_separator=" ", decimal_point=",",
        positive_sign="", trailing_positive_sign="",
        negative_sign="-", trailing_negative_sign="",
        rounding_method=ROUND_HALF_EVEN)
```

items.title: Convert formatted money via format_money back to original Money object
items.body: I want to convert formatted money via `format_money` method back to original `Money` object. I can't seem to find a solution for that. Can someone help?

items.title: CFH (Swiss Franc) currency listed under Liechtenstein
items.body: While this currency is used in Liechtenstein, it should also list it as being used in Switzerland.

items.title: Outdated currencies and country
items.body:
I found an old currency and country in the library: ANG and [Netherlands Antilles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Netherlands_Antilles) that was dissolved on 2010, they split into:
- [Curaçao](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cura%C3%A7ao) with currency code ANG
- [Sint Maarten](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sint_Maarten) with currency code ANG
- The rest of the islands seems to be now special Netherlands provinces

items.title: New release request
items.body:
Hi! I'm using `py-moneyed` through `django-money` and since I'm from Czech Republic, I need to use CZK currency. In 0.7.0, this currency is wrongly formatted as prefix. This issue has been already resolved in #93.

I noticed, that there are no more formatting changes accepted due to #22, but since this is already fixed and only requires release to PyPI, I kindly ask you to issue a new release at your convenience. Thank you!

items.title: TypeError: Cannot add or subtract a Money and non-Money instance.
items.body:
I have a test code:

```
#!/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: UTF-8 -*-

from moneyed import Money								
x = Money(amount='0.01', currency='USD')

words = 'alphabet'

for i in words:
	x += 0.01

print (x)
```

Not sure why when I run it it returns me:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "test.py", line 10, in <module>
    x += 0.01
  File "C:\Program Files\Python36\lib\site-packages\moneyed\classes.py", line 124, in __add__
    'Money and non-Money instance.')
TypeError: Cannot add or subtract a Money and non-Money instance.
```

it seems like the `+=` won't work

items.title: UIC-Franc no longer in ISO-4217 list.
items.body:
UIC-Franc was replaced by the Euro

https://www.currency-iso.org/dam/isocy/downloads/dl_currency_iso_amendment_157.pdf

items.title: Division error at Python 2.7
items.body:
For some weird reason i am getting errors with division at python 2.7

That is my ipython session that replicates the error:
```
In [1]: from moneyed.classes import Money,  CURRENCIES

In [2]: Money(amount=10, currency=CURRENCIES['USD']) / 2
---------------------------------------------------------------------------
TypeError                                 Traceback (most recent call last)
<ipython-input-2-5831df76cb8f> in <module>()
----> 1 Money(amount=10, currency=CURRENCIES['USD']) / 2

TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for /: 'Money' and 'int'
```

The strange part is that running the tests from project test file using pytest it passes without getting any errors with division, but, outside that i get this error.

items.title: Default locale is not used
items.body:
When there are missing translations for currencies in specific locale, the default translation is not used. I.e. when I want to use EURO in 'pl_PL' locale py-moneyed displays `EUR` rather than `€` suffix.

The only way to make it work is to add a custom translation: `_sign('pl_PL', moneyed.EUR, suffix=' €')`.

items.title: New release request
items.body: There's some bug fixes, for example this one, https://github.com/limist/py-moneyed/commit/b6ff01eaf77302f295c084531222bfd6b96b42ae, which are not in the latest release (0.6). Can we have a new release to pick these up?

items.title: Missing currency codes
items.body: There are 16 currencies missing from this library which are in the official list (http://www.iso.org/iso/home/standards/currency_codes.htm)

items.title: Refactor add_currency()
items.body:
Hi, I don't know if that's the desired structure of the code, but I was wondering if there's a specific need for all the Currency objects created by the final part of classes.py. After all, these objects are accessed via the CURRENCIES dict.

If there's no such specific need, I refactored classes.py so that CURRENCIES and CURRENCIES_BY_ISO get the objects from a loop. I eventually eliminated the add_currency() function. I'm creating a PR for that, merge it if you will, ok?

items.body:
@limist Kai - if you could set up TravisCI for this repo, that would be a real help. There is already a Travis config file, all you need to do is sign up at https://travis-ci.org and click a few buttons. It would mean we get the test suite running on pull requests, for much faster feedback, and the ability to link to specific failures etc.

Thanks!

items.title: Confusing Money.__repr__
items.body:
It's odd to display a value different from the actual one. Take a look:

```
In [20]: a, b
Out[20]: (17 XYZ, 17 XYZ)

In [21]: a == b  # They're equal, right?
Out[21]: False

In [22]: a.amount, b.amount  # Nope. Here's why:
Out[22]: (Decimal('17.77'), Decimal('17.78'))
```

Here's the `Money.__repr__` method: https://github.com/limist/py-moneyed/blob/master/moneyed/classes.py#L80
Could you explain why is it doing that?

items.title: Please add some docs
items.body:
Please add some docs.

My use case: How can I sum a list of Money instances?

items.title: pip installs from git don't work correctly with pip freeze.
items.body:
This is actually a bug with `pip freeze`, but having looked into it, it seems like a fix at that end is going to be really difficult or unlikely to be merged, so I'm filing here first.

If you do something like:

```
pip install -e git+https://github.com/limist/py-moneyed/@f9f4b8c4bfdded3433fbc88cd478d90ab2670eb0
```

And then do:

```
pip freeze
```

you will find that instead of listing the git URL, it shows:

```
py-moneyed==0.5.0
```

(Tested with latest pip==7.1.0). This is due to a bug in pip freeze, which assumes that the directory containing the installed module is the top-level VCS dir.

In the case of py-moneyed, the installed module ends up in: `/your/virtualenv/src/py-moneyed/src`. This is due to the folder layout, in which `moneyed` is within `src/`, instead of one level up, which seems to be the norm in every other Python project I can find (I did a quick scan down 10-15 projects on [PyPI](https://pypi.python.org/pypi), and every one where I could quickly find the source used the other convention).

Technically this is a bug in pip. But looking into it, it's going to be extremely difficult or impossible for them to fix. When it comes to doing `pip freeze`, pip has a list of directories where modules are found. The only way to correctly detect a VCS install is to look in the directory for `.git` (etc.), and then recurse upwards. However, once you start recursing upwards, you risk all kinds of issues - for example, traversing file system boundaries which could trigger permission errors, network errors (for network mounted folders) etc. etc. I imagine the maintainers of pip are not going to want to include that behaviour, especially when the current approach, while incorrect, works really well for most Python projects.

So, I suggest that everything in `src/` gets pulled up one level. This is as simple as:

```
git mv src/moneyed .
```

and then fixing the setup.py file. I'm very happy to submit a PR for this if you accept it - it's a really simple change. I've also checked that this doesn't screw things up with regards to existing patches and pull requests, and git seems to handle this fine.

items.title: Moneyed does not implement __nonzero__
Missing countries using Euro (EUR)
items.body:
Hello dev,

I'm going to use your library for a personal project but I spotted some missing countries that are officially using EUR (Euro).

As example, Vatican City seems missing.
Could you please add them and double-check the EUR list?

Many thanks,

Nicholas

References:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_4217
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vatican_City

items.title: Money does automatic conversion of floats, which is extremely unhelpful
items.body:
Compare:

```
>>> from decimal import Decimal
>>> Decimal("2.3") * 1.2
TypeError: unsupported operand type(s) for *: 'decimal.Decimal' and 'float'
```

There are extremely good reasons for this behaviour, and it is one of the primary reasons that you would choose to use Decimal to represent money. A decimal library must _never_ do a lossy conversion, and I use the Python Decimal module precisely because I can rely on it to do this correctly, and throw an exception if I ever make the mistake (and it's always a mistake) of mixing floats into my decimal calculations.

With py-moneyed, on the other hand:

```
>>> Money(amount='2.30', currency='USD') * 1.2
2 USD
```

I find this very surprising for a library designed to handle money. It should surely throw an exception instead.
